commander.name: Général de Brigade Marie-Pierre Koenig
commander.previous_service: Commanded Free French forces in Syria-Lebanon campaign

rifle_smle_no1_mkiii.description: Lee-Enfield No.1 Mk III rifle .303 (British standard issue)

bren_gun.description: Bren Mk I/II light machine gun .303

vickers_mmg.description: Vickers Mk I medium machine gun .303

tanks.notes: Brigade had NO tanks. Relied on British armored support when needed. Had 63 Bren Gun Carriers (Universal Carriers) for reconnaissance and infantry support.

canon_75mm_mle_1897.description: Canon de 75mm modèle 1897 field gun (French 75) - 4 batteries of 6 guns each, 1er Régiment d'Artillerie
canon_75mm_mle_1897.notes: Motorized configuration. Famous French 75 field gun used by Free French artillery regiment.

2pdr_at_gun.description: Ordnance QF 2-pounder anti-tank gun (British supply) - 1e Compagnie Anti-Chars
2pdr_at_gun.notes: British-supplied anti-tank guns. Standard British 2-pdr issued to Free French forces.

anti_aircraft_artillery.notes: Light AA weapons organic to 1er Bataillon de Fusiliers-Marins (naval infantry anti-aircraft battalion) not separately counted. Integrated with infantry units.

mortar_2in.description: Ordnance ML 2-inch mortar (British supply) - Company level

mortar_3in.description: Ordnance ML 3-inch mortar (British supply) - Battalion level

universal_carrier.description: Universal Carrier (Bren Gun Carrier) - British supply
universal_carrier.notes: Used for reconnaissance, infantry support, AT gun towing. Armor: 7-10mm, armament: Bren LMG, Vickers MMG, 2-inch mortar.

trucks_3ton.notes: Primary transport for motorized infantry battalions.

workshop_vehicles.description: Workshop and repair vehicles - 1er Atelier Lourd de Réparation Auto

aircraft_notes: No organic air support. Relied on British RAF Desert Air Force for air cover and reconnaissance.

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for defensive operations. Dependent on British 8th Army logistics. Primary constraint: limited organic transport capacity. Reliant on British supply lines from Benghazi/Tobruk.
supply_logistics.notes: Supply chain through British 8th Army. Water critical in desert. Limited fuel reserves restrict operational mobility. 101e Compagnie Auto provides transport capability.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Libyan coastal desert and rocky plateau
weather_environment.notes: Winter quarter in North Africa. Cooler temperatures, occasional rain. Operation Crusader period (18 Nov - 20 Dec 1941). Terrain: mix of coastal plain and inland rocky desert plateau.

subordinate_units.notes: Elite Foreign Legion battalions. Battle-hardened from East Africa and Syria campaigns. Equipped with British weapons and equipment.

composition.notes: Pacific Islands volunteers (Tahiti, New Caledonia). Renowned for tenacity and courage.

subordinate_units.notes: Colonial troops from French overseas territories. Mixed French and colonial personnel.

subordinate_units.designation: 1er Régiment d'Artillerie des Forces Françaises Libres

equipment.description: 4 batteries with 6x Canon de 75mm modèle 1897 each

subordinate_units.notes: Officially formed Damascus December 1941. Motorized configuration. Most glorious pages written in Libyan desert.
Naval infantry battalion with anti-aircraft role. Light AA weapons integrated with brigade defense.
North African troops (likely Moroccan or Algerian). Attached for desert operations expertise.

composition.notes: Engineer company. Mine clearing, fortification, field works.
Transport company. Primary motorized transport for brigade.
Heavy vehicle repair workshop. Mobile maintenance capability.

personnel_breakdown.notes: 1er Groupe (1800) + 2e Groupe (2200) + Artillery (480) + Fusiliers-Marins (280) + 22e Cie NA (180) + Support Companies (490) + Brigade HQ (150) + Medical/Admin (420) = 5000

validation.equipment_notes: British-supplied equipment post-1940. Lee-Enfield rifles, Bren LMGs, Vickers MMGs, 2-pdr AT guns, Universal Carriers. French 75mm artillery retained from pre-war stocks.

historical_context.previous_designation: 1re Division Légère Française Libre (reorganized into brigade group)

major_operations.notes: Brigade participated in British offensive to relieve Tobruk. Defensive screening operations.

historical_context.equipment_transition: Fully re-equipped with British Commonwealth standard equipment by Q4 1941. Lee-Enfield rifles, Bren guns, Vickers MMGs, 2-pdr AT guns, Universal Carriers, British trucks. Retained French 75mm artillery from pre-war stocks.
historical_context.next_major_action: Battle of Bir Hakeim (May-June 1942) - Brigade's most famous action

extraction_metadata.notes: Free French forces documentation limited in local sources. Relied on Tier 2 curated web sources (Ordre de la Libération, French Foreign Legion Information, military history sites). All Wikipedia sources excluded per project requirements. Equipment data based on British Commonwealth standard issue patterns for Free French forces in 1941. Artillery regiment formed December 1941 per French official sources.
